document.title: Arizona College and Career Ready Standards – Mathematics

D548E9C0DFE30131535368A86D17958E.description: Apply geometric methods to solve design problems (e.g., designing an object or structure to satisfy physical constraints or minimize cost; working with typographic grid systems based on ratios).

D54880A0DFE30131535268A86D17958E.description: Apply concepts of density based on area and volume in modeling situations (e.g., persons per square mile, BTUs per cubic foot).
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

D5482610DFE30131535168A86D17958E.description: Use geometric shapes, their measures, and their properties to describe objects (e.g., modeling a tree trunk or a human torso as a cylinder).
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

D547CE20DFE30131535068A86D17958E.description: Apply geometric concepts in modeling situations

D5471A70DFE30131534E68A86D17958E.description: Identify the shapes of two-dimensional cross-sections of three-dimensional objects, and identify three-dimensional objects generated by rotations of two-dimensional objects.

D546BB80DFE30131534D68A86D17958E.description: Visualize relationships between two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects

D5466230DFE30131534C68A86D17958E.description: Use volume formulas for cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres to solve problems.

D5460420DFE30131534B68A86D17958E.description: (+) Give an informal argument using Cavalieri's principle for the formulas for the volume of a sphere and other solid figures.

comments: Use dissection arguments, Cavalieri's principle, and informal limit arguments.
D545A110DFE30131534A68A86D17958E.description: Give an informal argument for the formulas for the circumference of a circle, area of a circle, volume of a cylinder, pyramid, and cone.

D5453B00DFE30131534968A86D17958E.description: Explain volume formulas and use them to solve problems

D5445C90DFE30131534768A86D17958E.description: Use coordinates to compute perimeters of polygons and areas of triangles and rectangles, e.g., using the distance formula.
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

D543E760DFE30131534668A86D17958E.description: Find the point on a directed line segment between two given points that partitions the segment in a given ratio.

D5436D80DFE30131534568A86D17958E.description: Prove the slope criteria for parallel and perpendicular lines and use them to solve geometric problems (e.g., find the equation of a line parallel or perpendicular to a given line that passes through a given point).

comments: For example, prove or disprove that a figure defined by four given points in the coordinate plane is a rectangle; prove or disprove that the point (1, √3) lies on the circle centered at the origin and containing the point (0, 2).
D5430C00DFE30131534468A86D17958E.description: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically.

D542B790DFE30131534368A86D17958E.description: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically

D54261D0DFE30131534268A86D17958E.description: (+) Derive the equations of ellipses and hyperbolas given the foci, using the fact that the sum or difference of distances from the foci is constant.

D54208C0DFE30131534168A86D17958E.description: Derive the equation of a parabola given a focus and directrix.

D541AF20DFE30131534068A86D17958E.description: Derive the equation of a circle of given center and radius using the Pythagorean Theorem; complete the square to find the center and radius of a circle given by an equation.

D5414D70DFE30131533F68A86D17958E.description: Translate between the geometric description and the equation for a conic section

D5408950DFE30131533D68A86D17958E.description: Derive using similarity the fact that the length of the arc intercepted by an angle is proportional to the radius, and define the radian measure of the angle as the constant of proportionality; derive the formula for the area of a sector.

D54013E0DFE30131533C68A86D17958E.description: Find arc lengths and areas of sectors of circles

D53FB360DFE30131533B68A86D17958E.description: (+) Construct a tangent line from a point outside a given circle to the circle.

D53F4F30DFE30131533A68A86D17958E.description: Construct the inscribed and circumscribed circles of a triangle, and prove properties of angles for a quadrilateral inscribed in a circle.

comments: Include the relationship between central, inscribed, and circumscribed angles; inscribed angles on a diameter are right angles; the radius of a circle is perpendicular to the tangent where the radius intersects the circle.
D53EF330DFE30131533968A86D17958E.description: Identify and describe relationships among inscribed angles, radii, and chords.

D53E7A10DFE30131533868A86D17958E.description: Prove that all circles are similar.

D53E0840DFE30131533768A86D17958E.description: Understand and apply theorems about circles

D53CF3F0DFE30131533468A86D17958E.description: (+) Understand and apply the Law of Sines and the Law of Cosines to find unknown measurements in right and non-right triangles (e.g., surveying problems, resultant forces).

D53C9B30DFE30131533368A86D17958E.description: (+) Prove the Laws of Sines and Cosines and use them to solve problems.

D53D4C30DFE30131533568A86D17958E.description: (+) Derive the formula A = 1/2 ab sin(C) for the area of a triangle by drawing an auxiliary line from a vertex perpendicular to the opposite side.

D53BDD30DFE30131533168A86D17958E.description: Use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean Theorem to solve right triangles in applied problems.
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

D53B6DF0DFE30131533068A86D17958E.description: Explain and use the relationship between the sine and cosine of complementary angles.

D53B0A80DFE30131532F68A86D17958E.description: Understand that by similarity, side ratios in right triangles are properties of the angles in the triangle, leading to definitions of trigonometric ratios for acute angles.

D53A9960DFE30131532E68A86D17958E.description: Define trigonometric ratios and solve problems involving right triangles

D53A3FE0DFE30131532D68A86D17958E.description: Use congruence and similarity criteria for triangles to solve problems and to prove relationships in geometric figures.

comments: Theorems include: a line parallel to one side of a triangle divides the other two proportionally, and conversely; the Pythagorean Theorem proved using triangle similarity.

D5391CD0DFE30131532A68A86D17958E.description: Use the properties of similarity transformations to establish the AA criterion for two triangles to be similar.

D5389BD0DFE30131532968A86D17958E.description: Given two figures, use the definition of similarity in terms of similarity transformations to decide if they are similar; explain using similarity transformations the meaning of similarity for triangles as the equality of all corresponding pairs of angles and the proportionality of all corresponding pairs of sides.

D5383A80DFE30131532868A86D17958E.description: The dilation of a line segment is longer or shorter in the ratio given by the scale factor.

D537D210DFE30131532768A86D17958E.description: A dilation takes a line not passing through the center of the dilation to a parallel line, and leaves a line passing through the center unchanged.

D5377C00DFE30131532668A86D17958E.description: Verify experimentally the properties of dilations given by a center and a scale factor:

D5372510DFE30131532568A86D17958E.description: Understand similarity in terms of similarity transformations

D53662E0DFE30131532368A86D17958E.description: Construct an equilateral triangle, a square, and a regular hexagon inscribed in a circle.

D535F470DFE30131532268A86D17958E.description: Make formal geometric constructions with a variety of tools and methods (compass and straightedge, string, reflective devices, paper folding, dynamic geometric software, etc.). Copying a segment; copying an angle; bisecting a segment; bisecting an angle; constructing perpendicular lines, including the perpendicular bisector of a line segment; and constructing a line parallel to a given line through a point not on the line.

comments: Theorems include: opposite sides are congruent, opposite angles are congruent, the diagonals of a parallelogram bisect each other, and conversely, rectangles are parallelograms with congruent diagonals.

Theorems include: measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°; base angles of isosceles triangles are congruent; the segment joining midpoints of two sides of a triangle is parallel to the third side and half the length; the medians of a triangle meet at a point.

Theorems include: vertical angles are congruent; when a transversal crosses parallel lines, alternate interior angles are congruent and corresponding angles are congruent; points on a perpendicular bisector of a line segment are exactly those equidistant from the segment's endpoints.
D5353A50DFE30131532068A86D17958E.description: Prove theorems about lines and angles.

D533C8F0DFE30131531C68A86D17958E.description: Explain how the criteria for triangle congruence (ASA, SAS, and SSS) follow from the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions.

D5335DE0DFE30131531B68A86D17958E.description: Use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to show that two triangles are congruent if and only if corresponding pairs of sides and corresponding pairs of angles are congruent.

D53302D0DFE30131531A68A86D17958E.description: Use geometric descriptions of rigid motions to transform figures and to predict the effect of a given rigid motion on a given figure; given two figures, use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to decide if they are congruent.

D532A990DFE30131531968A86D17958E.description: Understand congruence in terms of rigid motions

D5324220DFE30131531868A86D17958E.description: Given a geometric figure and a rotation, reflection, or translation, draw the transformed figure using, e.g., graph paper, tracing paper, or geometry software. Specify a sequence of transformations that will carry a given figure onto another.

D531EB80DFE30131531768A86D17958E.description: Develop definitions of rotations, reflections, and translations in terms of angles, circles, perpendicular lines, parallel lines, and line segments.

D53193C0DFE30131531668A86D17958E.description: Given a rectangle, parallelogram, trapezoid, or regular polygon, describe the rotations and reflections that carry it onto itself.

D5313400DFE30131531568A86D17958E.description: Represent transformations in the plane using, e.g., transparencies and geometry software; describe transformations as functions that take points in the plane as inputs and give other points as outputs. Compare transformations that preserve distance and angle to those that do not (e.g., translation versus horizontal stretch).

D530C530DFE30131531468A86D17958E.description: Know precise definitions of angle, circle, perpendicular line, parallel line, and line segment, based on the undefined notions of point, line, distance along a line, and distance around a circular arc.

D53064B0DFE30131531368A86D17958E.description: Experiment with transformations in the plane

7681EF13ADB14E0BBDAF193C89CF22B0.description: Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning.

0ECD72982A3C4A319CA1336A4894BAB7.description: Look for and make use of structure.

1F128A2E40E64084841FF55108D596AB.description: Construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others.

A14B15AF83F74A43A3EB032B5510B83F.description: Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them.
